issues.text: Whether the certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution is valid and the appeal is maintainable thereunder, given the mechanical grant without reasons or exercise of judicial discretion?

anchor.surface_text: At the outset the learned counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh ( the respondent ) raised a preliminary objection to the hearing of the appeal on the ground that the certificate granted in the terms quoted above is not in full compliance with the provisions of Article 134 1 c of the Constitution. It was contended that the High Court should have granted the certificate after examining the case of each individual accused

issues.text: Whether the courts below erred in relying upon the evidence of the four eye-witnesses when their statements in court were at variance with their statements as recorded by the investigating Sub-Inspector?

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants raised four questions before us, namely, 1 that the courts below were in error in relying upon the evidence of the four eye-witnesses aforesaid when their statements in court were at variance with their statements as recorded by the investigating Sub-Inspector

issues.text: Whether the courts below erred in convicting and sentencing the appellants on the testimony of the four eye-witnesses when their evidence had not been acted upon in respect of other accused acquitted by the courts below?

anchor.surface_text: 2 that the courts below were in error in convicting and sentencing the appellants on the testimony of those four eye-witnesses when their evidence had not been acted upon in respect of the other accused who had been acquitted by the courts below

issues.text: Whether, the evidence of the four eye-witnesses having been disbelieved by the High Court in respect of some accused to whom specific parts were attributed, it should have been accepted in respect of other accused to whom no such parts were assigned?

anchor.surface_text: 3 that the evidence of those four eye-witnesses having been disbelieved by the lower appellate court, particularly in respect of some of those accused persons to whom they had attributed specific parts, should, not have been accepted in respect of those accused to whom no such parts had been assigned

issues.text: Whether the courts below erred in law in convicting the accused persons against whom no specific parts had been deposed to and whose mere presence in the assembly had been penalized?

anchor.surface_text: and 4 that the courts below had erred in law in convicting those accused persons against whom no specific parts had been deposed to and whose mere presence, in the assembly had been penalized. It is manifest that the first three grounds do not make out a case for special leave but we think that the fourth ground does.

issues.text: Whether mere presence in an unlawful assembly is sufficient to make a person a member thereof and liable under Section 149 IPC, or whether an overt act or something under Section 142 IPC is required?

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly, or unless the case falls under Section 142, Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: The certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is not in full compliance with the provisions as it was granted mechanically without examining each individual accused's case or exercising judicial discretion.

arguments.court_reasoning: Mere presence insufficient; acquitted Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo, Jagdish without overt acts; upheld for others with specific roles or presence throughout.

arguments.claim: Mere presence in an assembly does not make a person a member of unlawful assembly unless overt act shown or case falls under Section 142 IPC.

arguments.claim: High Court erred by acquitting accused whose names not in Sub-Inspector's tainted record, despite condemning the record as unreliable.

anchor.surface_text: Having held that the four eye-witnesses were on the whole reliable and that the record of their statements made by the investigating Sub-Inspector was not honest and faithful, the High Court fell into the error of acquitting all those accused persons, appellants before it, whose names did not find a place in the record made by that police officer.

arguments.claim: Police records are not substantive evidence but for testing veracity; if tainted, lose value; court must weigh in-court evidence accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Statements made by prosecution witnesses before the investigating police officer being the earliest statements made by them with reference to the facts of the occurrence are valuable material for testing the veracity of the witnesses examined in court... but the statements made during police investigation are not substantive evidence.

holdings.text: The certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is invalid as it was granted mechanically without exercise of judicial discretion or reasons apparent on the face of the order.

anchor.surface_text: We have no to determine whether that is so. That case lays down three propositions--  1  that the mere grant of a certificate does not prevent this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted and whether the conditions pre-requisite to the grant are satisfied  2  that the only condition is the exercise or a judicial discretion by the High Court  3  that being a judicial discretion, it must be exercised along well established lines governing an exercise of judicial discretion and  4  if the discretion is properly exercised on well established and proper lines, then, as in all cases where an exercise of discretion is involved, there would be no interference except on very strong grounds. We have no to apply these principles to the present case. Article 134 1  a  and  b  lay down two conditions which confer a right of appeal to this Court. That in itself indicates that normally there is no right of appeal in any other type of case. The only exception is  c  where a right is conferred  an appeal shall lie  if the High Court certifies that the case is a fit one for appeal. Now the word certifies is a strong word. It indicates that the High Court must bring its mind to bear on the question and, as in all cases of judicial orders and certificates, the reasons for the order must be apparent on the face of the order itself. The Supreme Court must be in a position to know first that the High Court has applied its mind to the matter and not acted mechanically and, secondly, exactly what the High Courts difficulty is and exactly what question of outstanding difficulty or importance the High Court feels this Court ought to settle. It is not enough to say leave to appeal is given and no more because an appeal is not allowed in the ordinary, way when conditions  a  and  b  are not satisfied. Accordingly merely to say that leave is given and no more is tantamount to saying that the High Court will usurp the functions of the Constitution-makers and allow the whole case to be opened up despite the fact that the Constitution has specifically limited the normal right of appeal to Sub-articles  a , and  b  and has left  c  to meet extraordinary cases. Now, in the present case, where the High Court has merely said Leave to appeal to the Supreme Court is granted. It is impossible for us to gather what induced the High Court to grant this leave or what points of outstanding importance that require to be settled are, in the opinion of the High Court, involved. The learned Judges have not even certified that this is a fit case for appeal. Had some reasons been given and the I point or points that it was felt we ought to settle been indicated that might have been treated as a curable irregularity in its procedure. But, as it is, we can only regard this omission as indicative of the fact that the High Court did not realise the responsibility that is cast upon it by Article 134 1   c  and did not realise that its discretion has to be judicially and not mechanically exercised. Accordingly, following our previous decision, we are unable to regard this appeal as properly certified and so decline to accept it as an appeal under Sub-article  c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Nar Singh v. State of UP: certificate requires judicial discretion with reasons apparent; mere 'leave granted' insufficient, not curable.

holdings.text: The appeal is entertained under Article 136 as the fourth ground raises substantial question warranting special leave.

anchor.surface_text: In fairness to the learned Judges we have been at pains to see whether there are matters which would have afforded them justification for granting a certificate under Sub-article  c . Four grounds were put forward before us on behalf of the appellants three of which are pure grounds of fact. Now it is clear that a certificate cannot be granted under Sub-article  c  if the High Court is in doubt about the facts. If there is doubt in the minds of the learned Judges about the facts, their duty is to acquit They cannot convict and then issue a certificate because they cannot make up their minds about the facts. The fourth ground taken before us involves a question of law but it is clear that that was not present to the minds of of the learned Judges because they do not even discuss it or advert to it. We are therefore constrained to hold that the appeal does not lie under Sub-article  c . But that still leaves us a discretion to examine whether this is a fit case for us to exercise our special powers under Article 136 1 , and that we now proceed to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fourth ground on mere presence merits interference under Art 136 discretion.

holdings.text: The first three grounds challenging reliability and consistency of eye-witness evidence do not merit special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the first three grounds do not make out a case for special leave but we think that the fourth ground does.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purely factual disputes not substantial for SL.

holdings.text: The first three grounds challenging reliability and consistency of eye-witness evidence do not merit special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the first three grounds do not make out a case for special leave but we think that the fourth ground does.

holdings.text: Mere presence in an assembly does not make a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless an overt act is shown or the case falls under Section 142 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly, or unless the case falls under Section 142, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle applied; distinguishes members from spectators.

holdings.text: Courts below erred in convicting accused solely on mere presence without specific overt acts; High Court erred by acquitting based on tainted police record instead of in-court evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Having held that the four eye-witnesses were on the whole reliable and that the record of their statements made by the investigating Sub-Inspector was not honest and faithful, the High Court fell into the error of acquitting all those accused persons, appellants before it, whose names did not find a place in the record made by that police officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police records only for testing veracity, not substantive; tainted record loses value; weigh in-court evidence.

holdings.text: Statements to police during investigation are not substantive evidence but valuable only for testing veracity of court testimony.

anchor.surface_text: Statements made by prosecution witnesses before the investigating police officer being the earliest statements made by them with reference to the facts of the occurrence are valuable material for testing the veracity of the witnesses examined in court... but the statements made during police investigation are not substantive evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: If record tainted, diminished value; court weighs in-court evidence accordingly.

holdings.text: Convictions under Sections 148, 302/149, 201/149, 452 IPC upheld for Baladin Lodhi, Parichhat Lodhi (both), Ajodhia Lodhi as active participants with overt acts in trespass and murder.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be the least doubt that those who had trespassed into the first floor of the house of Mangal Singh and killed those three refugees who had gone upstairs to have their breakfast were certainly up to their neck in the conspiracy and were thus very active members of the unlawful assembly. In that category are Baladin Lodhi, Parichhat, son of Lallu Lodhi, Ajodhia Lodhi and Parichhat, son of Sadhoo. They have therefore been rightly convicted and sentenced by the court below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific roles in shooting and trespass in pursuance of common object.

holdings.text: Conviction and sentence upheld for Raja Ram under relevant sections as he dragged and assaulted victim.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Raja Ram is a close neighbour of Mangal Singh. He has been assigned a distinct part in the occurrence that morning. He is said to have dragged Mela Singh out of the grain room of Mangal Singh on the first floor. He is also said to have given an axe blow to Mela Singh... His conviction and sentence must therefore be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overt acts deposed; history of enmity; active role.

holdings.text: Convictions upheld for Uma Charan under Sections 148, 302/149, 201/149 as he assaulted with sword and participated in burning bodies.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Uma Charan had also been named by all the four eye-witnesses as having taken a leading part in the occurrence. He was said not only to have hit Mela Singh on the head with a sword but was also one of those who took part in the burning of the dead bodies... His appeal must therefore-also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent testimony on overt acts furthering common object including disposal.

holdings.text: Convictions upheld for Mahabir under Sections 148, 302/149, 201/149, 452 as he dragged victim and present throughout.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Mahabir Pershad has his cattle shed adjacent to the north of Mangal Singhs house... He is also said to have dragged out Mela Singh from the place where he had been concealed... Apparently he had been there from beginning to end. His appeal must therefore also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proven overt acts; location implicates active participation.

holdings.text: Convictions upheld for Narain Das under relevant sections as he incited the mob.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Narain Das was the Mukhia of the village... He has been assigned the specific part of inciting the mob from near the chhabutra of Mahabir. Hence the evidence of the four eye-witnesses directly implicating him in the crime... The courts below were therefore fully justified... His appeal must also stand dismissed.

holdings.text: Convictions upheld for Ramola (chowkidar) under Sections 148, 302/149, 201/149 for false report shielding culprits.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Ramola is the village chowkidar. Instead of keeping the police informed... he went as late as 5 p.m. to the police station to lodge the report that all was well... This serious dereliction of duty... The courts below were therefore justified in convicting him... His appeal must also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dereliction furthers common object by concealing crime.

holdings.text: Convictions upheld for Vir Singh alias Vira Lodhi and Mannu Teli for roles in transporting and burning bodies.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Vir Singh alias Vira Lodhi had, according to the prosecution case, set the ball rolling... He is further alleged to have taken three of the dead bodies in his cart... Appellant Mannu Teli also is assigned the specific part of carrying three of the dead bodies on his cart... His appeal was also rightly dismissed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overt acts in disposal part of common object; recoveries corroborate.

holdings.text: Conviction upheld for Jangi under relevant sections (sentence reduced) as ring-leader with axe assault.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider the case of the only appellant Jangi... Besides being named... he was also alleged to have struck Mela Singh... with an axe... Hence it cannot be said that he was a mere sightseer...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eye-witness identification; Sessions finding as ring-leader; police record lapse not fatal.

holdings.text: Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish acquitted as no specific overt acts attributed; possibly mere spectators.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider the cases of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish. These four appellants had not been assigned any particular part in the occurrence no any overt act has been attributed to them... They might possibly have been spectators who got mixed up in the crowd. They will, therefore, be given the benefit of the doubt and acquitted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of membership beyond presence; benefit of doubt.

precedents.case_name: Nar Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles for grant of certificate under Article 134(1)(c): Supreme Court can examine if properly granted; requires judicial discretion exercised on well-established lines; no interference if properly exercised

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider the cases of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish. These four appellants had number been assigned any particular part in the occurrence number any overt act has been attributed to them. Of these, Thakur Das is a resident of another village in another police station, though he has cultivation in village Goran. They might possibly have been spectators who got mixed up in the crowd. They will, therefore, be given the benefit of the doubt and acquitted.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish allowed and they acquitted; appeals of other 13 appellants in C.A. No. 118/1954 and Jangi in C.A. No. 119/1954 dismissed with convictions and sentences upheld.

edges.explanation: The holding directly rules on the validity of the High Court certificate under Article 134(1)(c) raised as the core issue.

anchor.surface_text: We have no to determine whether that is so. That case lays down three propositions--  1  that the mere grant of a certificate does not prevent this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted and whether the conditions pre-requisite to the grant are satisfied  2  that the only condition is the exercise or a judicial discretion by the High Court  3  that being a judicial discretion, it must be exercised along well established lines governing an exercise of judicial discretion and  4  if the discretion is properly exercised on well established and proper lines, then, as in all cases where an exercise of discretion is involved, there would be no interference except on very strong grounds. We have no to apply these principles to the present case. Article 134 1  a  and  b  lay down two conditions which confer a right of appeal to this Court. That in itself indicates that normally there is no right of appeal in any other type of case. The only exception is  c  where a right is conferred  an appeal shall lie  if the High Court certifies that the case is a fit one for appeal. Now the word certifies is a strong word. It indicates that the High Court must bring its mind to bear on the question and, as in all cases of judicial orders and certificates, the reasons for the order must be apparent on the face of the order itself. The Supreme Court must be in a position to know first that the High Court has applied its mind to the matter and not acted mechanically and, secondly, exactly what the High Courts difficulty is and exactly what question of outstanding difficulty or importance the High Court feels this Court ought to settle. It is not enough to say leave to appeal is given and no more because an appeal is not allowed in the ordinary, way when conditions  a  and  b  are not satisfied. Accordingly merely to say that leave is given and no more is tantamount to saying that the High Court will usurp the functions of the Constitution-makers and allow the whole case to be opened up despite the fact that the Constitution has specifically limited the normal right of appeal to Sub-articles  a , and  b  and has left  c  to meet extraordinary cases. Now, in the present case, where the High Court has merely said Leave to appeal to the Supreme Court is granted. It is impossible for us to gather what induced the High Court to grant this leave or what points of outstanding importance that require to be settled are, in the opinion of the High Court, involved. The learned Judges have not even certified that this is a fit case for appeal. Had some reasons been given and the I point or points that it was felt we ought to settle been indicated that might have been treated as a curable irregularity in its procedure. But, as it is, we can only regard this omission as indicative of the fact that the High Court did not realise the responsibility that is cast upon it by Article 134 1   c  and did not realise that its discretion has to be judicially and not mechanically exercised. Accordingly, following our previous decision, we are unable to regard this appeal as properly certified and so decline to accept it as an appeal under Sub-article  c .

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly, or unless the case falls under Section 142, Indian Penal Code.

They will, therefore, be given the benefit of the doubt and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: Having held that the four eye-witnesses were on the whole reliable and that the record of their statements made by the investigating Sub-Inspector was not honest and faithful, the High Court fell into the error of acquitting all those accused persons, appellants before it, whose names did not find a place in the record made by that police officer.
